BE

We expect Sainsbury to request an extension of the Tuesday deadline to table a formal bid. The Home Retail board are likely to accept this, and a deadline may move to 18-March (in line with that imposed upon Steinhoff).
Sainsbury management have effectively ‘played their hand’ by tacitly admitting they expect to struggle if solely reliant on the current format to drive the P&L. Hence we would not be surprised if Sainsbury came back with a counter-bid in due course. We also note the emergence of another bidder should not be ruled out, with the other Food Retailers, in particular Asda, potentially interested.
Whilst Steinhoff have the deepest pockets and an ability to offer cash (achieving over EUR1bn FCF p.a. and levered at c.1x ND/EBITDA) we still believe the synergy opportunity is greater to the Food retailers (note our Food Retail colleagues estimated £160-200m of synergies could be achievable for Sainsbury).
The battle for Home Retail therefore centre’s on management’s conviction of a deal with diminishing returns. A Sainsbury counter-bid is likely, but we believe it is most likely that Steinhoff wins this battle. Should Walmart/Asda enter the fray, then the combination of balance sheet strength and greater synergies could see them as likely acquirers.
As a final thought, a Steinhoff acquisition followed by a roll-out of Argos implants in Sainsbury stores could offer both partners a strategic solution.

Given the all-cash offer from Steinhoff and its deeper pockets, our default expectation must be that eventually Steinhoff wins out, even though it seemingly lacks access to the same level of synergy. In this case, some of the recent negative share performance from Sainsbury could ultimately reverse. Don't get too excited though. Absent the optimism surrounding the importance of the Argos tie-up, the market is left with the tacit strategic concerns of Sainsbury management for a group operating as a pure-play food retailer.
Sainsbury has shown a clear desire to obtain the Argos asset, and has 'played its hand' in doing so, tacitly admitting that it expects to struggle if solely reliant on the Food business to drive the P&L. As such, we expect Sainsbury will come back with a counter-bid (could be Monday morning - the due diligence deadline is on Tuesday), though we think it will be unwilling to go near GB200p. We accordingly anticipate a counter-bid in the region of GBp185, and if so expect Sainsbury will also talk to a synergy figure above the GBP120m initially guided. BE

Steinhoff, which achieved a dual listing on the Frankfurt stock exchange in December 2015, is an integrated discount retailer that sources and manufactures furniture, household goods and clothing in low cost locations and retails them in Europe, Africa and Australasia. Steinhoff’s strategy is to grow revenue and market share through expanding its footprint, continuous investment in stores and e-commerce.
Steinhoff has historically been a very acquisitive company and has a proven track record for acquiring businesses and improving their margins (albeit it is financially leveraged). Steinhoff also has experience with the UK market through its two retail chains, Bensons for Beds and Harveys. However in recent years, Steinhoff has voiced its ambition to expand deeper into the European discount sector and in 2015 it acquired Pepkor which has enabled it to diversify more into General Merchandise. In the UK, 50 discount apparel stores (Pep & Co) were opened in 50 days.
From Steinhoff’s perspective, we think a potential bid for Home Retail is attractive as 1) it further diversifies the Group away from Africa, 2) it gives Steinhoff exposure to the discount variety format which they have been trying to do in the UK, 3) Argos’ product categories (homewares, electricals etc) would be complementary to Steinhoff’s existing UK furniture and clothing offer, and 4) it would provide Steinhoff with a more developed multichannel platform. Steinhoff is fairly underdeveloped online (Conforama has the highest penetration at 7% of sales) and so we believe this would be big step forward in this respect given Argos is arguably the market leader in this field.

BE

We think that Sainsbury’s may well now consider a higher bid given that on paper it looks like there are a lot of strategic and financing benefits of a tie up with Home Retail. Sainsbury’s would benefit from the take-up of excess food space and standalone Argos closures, allowing Sainsbury’s to offer a full food and nonfood offer across a more optimised store estate. Sainsbury’s has also been able to keep the cost of deal relatively low by effectively refinancing Argos’ £600m loan book by moving it into the Sainsbury’s bank division of the business and generating cash for the core business. Therefore we think the deal would also be attractive from a financial leverage perspective given debt owed by the bank is excluded from Sainsbury’s reported net debt.

We believe that Steinhoff could afford to fund this acquisition 100% through debt since we estimate the acquisition would only take the business to 4.0x lease-adjusted net debt/EBITDAR on a proforma FY Jun-16 basis. However, Steinhoff also has potential flexibility with: the possibility of disposing of Home’s £550m customer credit book, 200m shares currently held in treasury (worth £720m), historic willingness to issue equity and a supportive shareholder structure (c35% held in a voting pool).

BE

Assuming 100% debt funding at 5% borrowing cost then we estimate the deal would be broadly neutral to EPS pre-synergies (each 1% higher interest = 2% off EPS). However, with Home a 1.6% EBIT margin business then accretion and value-creation is highly sensitive to any synergies achieved. Each 1% on Home’s margins would add 5% to combined EPS. Areas of potential are: 1) COGS savings on Home’s c€3.6bn annual cost base, since across electricals, furniture & home there is c70% category overlap with Steinhoff, 2) a little property rationalization of the c720 standalone Argos with Steinhoff’s c450 UK furniture stores & 50 Pep & Co’s, albeit we do not see a Shop Within A Shop UK opportunity like at Sainsbury’s, 3) leverage of Home’s furniture and fitted furniture brands like Habitat and Schreiber across Steinhoff’s businesses, 4) a roll out of the Argos model might be interesting in Europe or Africa if consumers can be ‘educated’ to the proposition, 5) cross-selling ranges back into Argos, 6) central cost savings. Beyond deal execution and synergy extraction, risks include: 1) relatively ‘late’ cycle position of UK consumers, 2) ongoing competitive pressures on Argos from Amazon and Dixons Carphone.

BE

There is some evidence to support the view that investors are becoming increasingly sensitive to referendum risk. In particular it is noticeable that GBP failed to gain much advantage from the improvement in recent weeks in the 2-year yield differential against Germany. The most likely explanation for is the three polls published in early February (YouGov, YouGov/Times, ICM) showing a lead for those in favour of an exit from the European Union. Most notably the YouGov poll (commissioned by the Times) published on February 5 showed that those in favour of a 'Brexit' stood at 45% compared with 36% against, whilst 19% remained undecided. This poll was undertaken shortly after the publication of Prime Minister David Cameron's tentative deal on reform with the EU. These polls in favour of an exit followed on from similar results that emerged in two surveys in early January along with a small number in November and December of last year.
This sensitivity to referendum risk bears comparison with how events played out in the run up to the Scottish referendum in 2014. GBP had remained largely immune to referendum talk through the first eight months of the year despite a narrowing of the gap between the two camps from February onwards. This changed in early September 2014 following the publication of a poll in The Sunday Times showing the independence camp in the lead. Given this was the first survey since August 2013 to show this, it caught the attention of investors. Despite the fact that only one other poll (ICM/Sunday Telegraph) published in the run up to the vote showed the "exit" camp in the lead, GBP remained volatile throughout this period.
Although it is impossible to say if the weakness seen in GBP today is principally a reflection of the announcement of the date of the vote itself or whether it also reflects a collective belief that political events over the weekend have shifted the odds on the outcome very slightly, the price action is nevertheless already giving a clue as to how referendum risk could impact the currency in the weeks ahead. We will explore this in greater depth over the next few days.

12: Does GBP's performance ahead of a major political event tell us a great deal about what will happen afterwards?
Not necessarily. GBP proved highly sensitive to the changing expectations of a coalition government ahead of the general election in 2010 (with GBP losing ground when expectations of a coalition rose). However, GBP trended steadily higher in the aftermath of the election despite the formation of a coalition government. It is also worth recalling that GBP strength in the aftermath of the Scottish referendum was fading even before the final results were announced.

BE

To date, there is no evidence (at least through the BoE agents) that the risk of
Brexit is postponing investment intentions. In a ‘Brexit’ the UK would lose its
credit rating and there would be more focus on the UK’s current account deficit
and how that would be funded in a world where reserve managers held fewer
Gilts(see RHS chart). Sterling would undoubtedly fall. And, to further throw
into the mix the Scottish issue would come back onto the agenda, as the SNP
pushed again for a referendum to break up the Union. For the BoE, Brexit would
not just pose a significant challenge for monetary policy, but also to financial
stability, especially given London’s role as a financial centre, with a still large
banking sector with significant cross-EU exposure. In a Brexit scenario the UK
saving ratio could rise significantly.

BE

The actual technical issue of ‘leaving’ the EU is not necessarily that clear. It
would involve the UK ‘invoking’ article 50, the withdrawal clause in the EU treaties which
sets a renewable two year term to negotiate the terms of exit. In practice it could take up to
four years for the formal process to close.

Turning away from politics, the pound sterling has limped into 2016 on the
back of softer macro data and has dropped around 5% versus the euro while
the UK yield curve continues to flatten. Interestingly, negative CPI which has raised
concerns over deflation seems to be disappearing quicker than investors can perceive.
Although the headline CPI is 0.3% y-y, RPI is running at 1.3% but excluding fuel and light
prices are rising by 2.5%. The yield curve may not remain that flat for long!

Diagnosing the UK equity since the beginning of the year approximately 20% of
the FTSE All share index is now trading below book with around 25% trading
between one and two times. With the yield curve flat it makes sense to discriminate
stocks based on their Free Cash Flow (FCF) yield. 45% of the FTSE all share index trades on a
FCF yield between 5 to 10%. With real gilt yields close to 2% (and in line with US real
treasury yields), the UK equity market offers a FCF yield ex-financials of around 5% and a
FTSE 100 dividend yield of just over 4%. The equity market appears to be reasonably priced.

Our theme for 2016 has been the ‘growing shortage of income’ from the stock
market as more companies cut dividends in the wake of depressed commodity
prices and subdued top line growth. Taylor Wimpey (TW/LN, BUY, PT: GBp277),
Barratt Developments (BDEV LN, BUY, PT: GBp807), Inmarsat (ISAT LN, BUY, PT:
GBp1,245) and BBA Aviation (BBA LN, BUY, PT: GBp273) show implied dividend
increases over the next few years. In particular, income funds should welcome the visibility
of dividend afforded by Barratt's well-constructed land bank.

We have updated our Anglo model to reflect reported '15 results and some
changes to guidance. We are not yet modeling potential asset sales or other
restructuring other than some cost cutting. Based on our analysis, the risk to
the AAL share price is to the downside in the near term, especially after the
recent rally. Asset sales and cost cutting in line with aggressive guidance would
be clear long-term positives but will be difficult to achieve in our view.
Core Anglo would be well positioned: Anglo's plan is to cut the number of assets in
its portfolio from 45 to 16, mostly via asset sales. The new, core Anglo would consist of De
Beers, most of Anglo Platinum, and the Los Bronces and Collahuasi copper mines as well as
the Quellaveco and Sakatti projects. Mgmt indicated that this core business would generate
$2.5bn of EBITDA at current spot prices and would have a targeted net debt level of $6bn.
This would be a highly competitive company in the mining industry. Core Anglo would be
cash generative through the cycle.
Restructuring will be a challenge: A successful transformation for Anglo depends on a
combination of asset sales and cost cutting. We are concerned that demand for higher cost
assets - especially in bulk commodities - will be weak, and buyers will only be interested
if assets will be sold at low valuations. Anglo is therefore likely to struggle to complete
its planned $3-4bn of divestments in '16 and $7bn+ of divestments in the longer term.
Delivering an additional $1.9bn of cost savings and business improvements in '16 will also
be difficult as cyclical cost deflation in mining is slowing. This is an uphill battle for Anglo.
Valuing the new core Anglo: If mgmt succeeds, the AAL share price would likely have
further upside, even after the recent rally. If we assume $2.5bn of core EBITDA at spot, an EV/
EBITDA multiple of 8x (reasonable for world class mining assets at a very weak point in the
cycle), and net debt of $6bn, Anglo's equity value would be 746p/sh. It really comes down
to whether these aggressive restructuring targets are met. In the near-term, we think Anglo's
share price depends on whether mgmt can convince investors these plans are credible. In
the longer term, Anglo's share price depends on whether these plans are actually achieved.

Since we're here, there's a long Deutsche Bank argument on oil from last week that we didn't get an opportunity to share.

BE

Why commodities will recover

BE

First we ask how low could oil realistically go? We examine the marginal cost of production and explain why oil could hit this level but probably won’t. There are many reasons for this but the main one is that it would likely result in so much capital expenditure being cut that production would slow in the very near term and result in a sharp V-shaped recovery.
Then we turn to the future for metals, which is more or less analogous to our view on oil. Given the plentiful supply in most metal markets, spot prices are about half the level at which miners can earn the 12-15 per cent return many have targeted. Deep cuts to capital expenditure since the 2012 peak and the natural resource depletion reduces supply even further. We conclude that 2016 could see a tipping point for prices although a price recovery for metals will take longer than for oil.
What are the implications for fixed income assets? Some corners of the market have suffered a torrid time during the commodity rout, particularly in America where energy and commodity companies comprise one-fifth of the high-yield market. But unlike in other industries, rising energy defaults more immediately lead to a recovery in prices thus capping default rates relatively quickly. We also show why – despite tighter spreads in Europe not necessarily implying continental firms are safer than their US counterparts – there may be pockets of value in European high yield.
Meanwhile, we think about what a recovery in oil prices means for certain emerging markets. Referencing DB’s vulnerability monitor we note that four out of the top five countries most sensitive to external economic shocks are heavily exposed to commodities. Most will remain vulnerable regardless, however one country stands as potentially attractive: Russia and by implication we are positive on the ruble too.
